channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: On a Corpse’s Wrist, an Emblem of Ukrainian Fortitude
item.description: When they pulled Serhiy Sova’s body from a grave in Izium, his wrist bore a bracelet in Ukraine’s colors, given to him by his children. The image has transfixed the nation.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Anna Lukinova
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators exhumed bodies at the site of a mass grave in Izium this month.

item.title: War Crimes Have Been Committed in Ukraine, U.N. Experts Say
item.description: A three-person Commission of Inquiry set up in April to investigate the conduct of hostilities in four areas of Ukraine laid out the graphic allegations in an unusually hard-hitting, 11-minute statement to the U.N Human Rights Council in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cell where Ukrainian detainees, including civilians, were allegedly interrogated and tortured at the central police station in Kupiansk.

item.title: Oil Prices Tumble to Their Lowest Level Since January
item.description: The U.S. benchmark oil price fell below $80 a barrel for the first time since the start of the year.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A refinery in Deer Park, Texas. The falling price of oil offers consumers some relief from inflation.

item.title: U.K. Government Goes Full Tilt on Tax Cuts and Free-Market Economics
item.description: The new administration’s plans are a break from the Boris Johnson era and represent a turn toward Thatcherism. The negative reaction from financial markets underscored the extent of the gamble.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Daniel Leal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, will be hoping that the measures can engineer at least the start of a solid economic recovery before a general election that must take place by January 2025.

item.title: British Pound Sinks as Markets React to U.K. Government Tax Cuts
item.description: Stocks, bonds and the pound were jolted by policy details from the new government that entailed a huge rise in borrowing.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Jason Karaian
item.media:credit: Andy Rain/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The British central bank has been fighting high inflation by raising interest rates seven times since December.

item.title: As Trump’s Legal Woes Mount, So Do Financial Pressures on Him
item.description: The lawsuit filed by New York’s attorney general is the latest indication of how an array of investigations is affecting the former president’s business and personal wealth.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Ben Protess, Matthew Goldstein and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Todd Anderson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The numerous investigations and lawsuits swirling around former President Donald J. Trump are creating new and significant financial pressures on him.

item.title: Trump Claims He Declassified Documents, but His Lawyers Don’t
item.description: Judges this week highlighted the gap between Mr. Trump’s public claims that he declassified everything and his lawyers’ reluctance to repeat that claim in a courtroom.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Jim Bourg/Reuters
item.media:description: A detailed property inventory of documents and other items seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate.

item.title: Hilary Mantel, Prize-Winning Author of Historical Fiction, Dies at 70
item.description: The two-time Booker Prize-winning author was known for “Wolf Hall” and two other novels based on the life of Thomas Cromwell.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Ellie Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hilary Mantel in 2020.

item.title: Hilary Mantel Books, Reviews and Interviews: A Reading Guide
item.description: Mantel’s body of work spanned memoir, short stories, essays — and, of course, historical fiction. Here’s a guide to her writing.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff
item.media:credit: Sahlan Hayes/Fairfax Media via Getty Images
item.media:description: With her usual spiky language and rich immediacy of detail, Hilary Mantel reinvigorated the historical fiction genre.

item.title: Lorne Michaels Discusses the ‘Year of Reinvention’ Coming to ‘S.N.L.’
item.description: The “Saturday Night Live” creator explains how the show is handling one of its biggest cast turnovers in decades and why he has no plans to retire.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Mary Ellen Matthews/NBC
item.media:description: Lorne Michaels on the set of “Saturday Night Live,” where a major cast overhaul is underway this season.

item.title: Federer-Nadal Rivalry Ends in a Doubles Match Partnership
item.description: One of the greatest rivalries in tennis history will end in harmony on Friday when Roger Federer plays his final competitive match with Rafael Nadal as his doubles partner.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Glyn Kirk/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rafael Nadal and Roger Federer at a practice for the Laver Cup on Thursday in London. They played each other 40 times during their careers, with Nadal winning 24 of the matches.

item.title: Alex Jones Says He’s ‘Done’ Apologizing to Sandy Hook Families
item.description: In testimony in a Connecticut trial to assess the damages done by his Sandy Hook lies, the Infowars fabulist lashed out.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Williamson
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Jones said that “the First Amendment will prevail” as he left the courthouse in Waterbury, Conn., on Thursday.

item.title: Election Deniers in Senate Races Shift to Appeal to Voters in Middle
item.description: “Stop the Steal” Republicans hoping to win over general-election voters are going through contortions — scrubbing websites, using coded language or simply saying different things to different audiences.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.media:description: Don Bolduc with his campaign staff during his primary night watch party. After his primary, he changed his mind on the 2020 election results he had long questioned.

item.title: The Midterm Election’s Most Dominant Toxic Narratives
item.description: Misleading and divisive posts about the Nov. 8 midterm vote have flooded social media. Here are three prevalent themes.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A discarded sign on a Washington street on election night in 2020. False claims of voter fraud are swirling online before the midterm elections this November.

item.title: Constance Wu, Fresh Off Her Book
item.description: In her memoir, “Making a Scene,” the actress reveals her isolation after those tweets, racism in her career and how she’s moving on.
item.dc:creator: Thessaly La Force
item.media:credit: Amy Harrity for The New York Times

item.title: New Real Estate Developments in NYC: More Floors, Fewer Apartments
item.description: New boutique condo towers, some with fewer apartments than the buildings they replace, are squandering high-density sites in Manhattan, urban planners say.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: A recently built 210-foot tower at 60 East 86th Street with 14 apartments, where prices ranged from about $7 million to over $19 million.

item.title: Why Russia Is Losing the War in Ukraine
item.description: A national security expert takes stock of what the U.S. got wrong about Putin — and how Ukraine is gaining momentum, seven months in.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Putin Will Get Whatever Result He Wants
item.description: Starting on Friday, people in four occupied regions of Ukraine will “vote” on whether to become a part of Russia. Here’s what that really means.
item.dc:creator: Sasha Vasilyuk
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural in a police station in Kupiansk, Ukraine, depicts a Russian soldier and a woman holding a Soviet flag.

item.title: Biden Has Helped the Quiet Revolution of Giving People Money
item.description: Dozens of pilot programs and the success of the Child Tax Credit show the merits of a guaranteed income.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo
item.media:credit: Cavan Images/Getty Images

item.title: The Wrong Trump Judge at the Right Time Can Wreak Havoc
item.description: To solve the problem of hyperpartisan judges, expand the federal judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Andrew Kelly/Reuters

item.title: Betrayal and Blackouts in Puerto Rico
item.description: It is our own people who rob and abuse us.
item.dc:creator: Israel Meléndez Ayala
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: Protesters outside the governor’s mansion La Fortaleza in San Juan, Puerto Rico in July.

item.title: What We Will Miss Most About Roger Federer
item.description: His legacy is not reflected in just his career stats.
item.dc:creator: Michael Steinberger
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: We Document Human Rights Violations. Israel Wants to Silence Us.
item.description: If the rest of the world lets this happen, Palestinians will have less recourse for the injustices they face.
item.dc:creator: Shawan Jabarin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Nasser Nasser/Associated Press
item.media:description: The office of Al-Haq, a human rights organization in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

item.title: Every Moment Can’t Be a 10 Out of 10
item.description: I’ve come to see the wisdom in not just seeking, but finding, joy in the mundane, in the unremarkable, even in the frankly boring.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wildman
item.media:credit: Karlotta Freier

item.title: A Shift in Crime
item.description: Murders are declining, but other crimes are still disrupting American life.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York will install two security cameras on every subway car.

item.title: The Pastors Being Driven Out by Trumpism
item.description: Why some evangelical pastors in the U.S. are quitting in large numbers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Stella Tan, Lynsea Garrison, Rachelle Bonja, Michael Benoist, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms for The New York Times

item.title: How to Exercise Safely Outside in the Fall and Winter
item.description: Here are a few ways to protect yourself from the elements, oncoming traffic and other threats that ramp up in the fall and winter months.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Guillem Casasús

item.title: The Republic
item.description: American democracy is under threat. But for some candidates and voters, democracy isn’t even the destination anymore.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times. Photo by Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: How A South African Town Became Buried in Sludge After A Diamond Mine Collapse
item.description: Waste from a diamond mine in South Africa grew ever higher as the ownership changed from De Beers to a billionaire to a Dubai-based retailer. The mining town paid the price.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Lynsey Chutel and Ilan Godfrey
item.media:credit: Ilan Godfrey for The New York Times
item.media:description: When a dam at a diamond mine burst in September in Jagersfontein, South Africa, it coated houses, cars and possessions in six miles of muck. At least one person died.

item.title: Zeldin Sees a Path to Becoming Governor. It Runs Through Brooklyn.
item.description: Representative Lee Zeldin, a Republican candidate for governor, is hoping for a realignment of political loyalties in parts of the borough, including those of Hasidic Jews.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos and Eliza Shapiro
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Lee Zeldin’s campaign schedule has included frequent stops to Hasidic neighborhoods across Brooklyn and the lower Hudson Valley over the last few weeks.

item.title: Major Covid Holdouts in Asia Drop Border Restrictions
item.description: Hong Kong, Taiwan and Japan have relaxed their pandemic rules, as they look to bolster their economies and play catch-up with much of the world.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Kimimasa Mayama/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Tourists in the Asakusa district of Tokyo earlier this month.

item.title: Where Online Hate Speech Can Bring the Police to Your Door
item.description: Battling far-right extremism, Germany has gone further than any other Western democracy to prosecute individuals for what they say online, testing the limits of free speech on the internet.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chief Prosecutor Frank-Michael Laue surrounded by case files, in the attic of the district attorney’s office in Göttingen, Germany in March, 2022.

item.title: Can You Get the New Covid Booster and Flu Shot at the Same Time?
item.description: Combining vaccines may be more convenient, experts said.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times

item.title: What Is Legionnaires’ Disease and How Can I Protect Myself?
item.description: Nearly one out of every 10 people who gets sick with Legionnaires’ dies because of complications from the illness. Here’s what to know about prevention, detection and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh

item.title: Why a Child’s Rude Behavior May Be Good for Development
item.description: The safer children feel, the more they can show their true selves — warts and all — experts say. And that’s good for their development.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Amélie Fontaine

item.title: Can Stimulating the Vagus Nerve Improve Mental Health?
item.description: On social media, exercises that aim to “tone” one of our body’s longest nerves have been touted as a cure-all for anxiety and other psychological ailments. Here’s what the research says.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Chloe Cushman

item.title: Why L.G.B.T.Q. Adults Are More Vulnerable to Heart Disease
item.description: Experts say that a leading cause of death often goes overlooked.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Simone Noronha

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
